describe the efficient storage and transportation of fluids, including gravity flow and natural phenomena such as aqueducts, water towers, winds, and currents;
explain the use of fluids in power generation and power transmission such as hydraulics, pneumatics, pumps, compressors, and turbomachinery; and
explain the impact of lift and drag on a moving object.
differentiate and compare the properties that distinguish a solid from a fluid;
define the characteristics of a fluid and identify different types of fluids, including gasses, liquids, Newtonian, and non-Newtonian;
define and list examples of compressible and incompressible fluids;
explain the properties of fluids, including density, specific weight, specific gravity, viscosity, and compressibility;
describe methods to measure and calculate the density, specific weight, specific gravity, viscosity, and compressibility of a Newtonian fluid;
calculate density, specific weight, and specific gravity for a variety of fluids from measured data;
explain the appropriate use of material reference frames and spatial reference frames, including boundary conditions, control surfaces, and control volumes;
identify and explain the variables in the ideal gas law and apply the ideal gas law to constructed problems;
explain the laws of conservation of energy and conservation of mass, including the algebraic version of Reynolds transport theorem; and
identify appropriate boundary conditions, including no-slip and ambient pressure boundary conditions in fluid flow.
describe the relationship between force, area, and pressure;
calculate force proportionalities in hydraulic and pneumatic cylinders using Pascal's law and explain the impact of the cylinders' diameter on the resultant force;
differentiate between atmospheric pressure, gauge pressure, and absolute pressure;
describe the working principles of a pressure gauge and measure fluid pressure using dial gauges and manometers;
calculate the buoyant force of floating and submerged objects according to Archimedes' principle; and
define and calculate hydrostatic pressure.
compare developing, fully developed, and steady-state Newtonian fluid flows in pipes and channels;
compare fluid flow profiles, including uniform and parabolic;
describe experimental measurements of fluid flow field lines, including stream, streak, and pathlines;
calculate volumetric flow rate in a steady state system using the continuity equation and conservation of mass;
explain how Bernoulli's equation relates to the total energy of a steady-state system;
calculate unknown variables in varying conditions, including changes in height, velocity, and cross-sectional area of a steady state system using Bernoulli's equation and the conservation of energy;
derive Torricelli's equation from Bernoulli's equation and calculate the exit velocity and mass flow rates of free jets;
calculate fluid flows in pipes, channels, and free jets using the Reynolds Transport theorem and conservation of mass; and
calculate the resultant force of a free jet at the outlet based on the density of the fluid, cross-sectional area, pressure, and velocity of the fluid.
differentiate turbulent and laminar flows;
calculate the Reynolds number of given flows to determine if the flows are turbulent or laminar;
define lift and drag as applied to fluid flows;
explain the relationship between viscosity and shear force in a fluid flow;
explain the variables of lift and drag formulas and how the variables relate to fluid flow; and
design an experiment to measure the drag coefficient for a solid body in a fluid flow.
differentiate between compressible and incompressible fluids and explain the effect of compressibility on the speed of sound through a fluid;
explain how density impacts the speed of sound through a fluid;
calculate and use the Mach number to model a fluid as compressible or incompressible; and
explain the effects on fluid, including shock waves, when the sound barrier is broken.
explain the function of weirs in an open channel and describe an application of weirs such as flow control or flow measurement;
calculate the fluid flow in open channels with different shapes, slopes, and weirs;
design an application of hydrostatics using the principle of buoyancy such as a boat, submarine, floating dock, or hot air balloon;
analyze and design a fluid device such as a clepsydra, water tower, pressure regulator, or nozzle using the principles of fluid dynamics;
describe applications and processes of different types of pumps, including centrifugal pumps, peristaltic pumps, gear pumps, and positive displacement pumps;
describe the operation of a centrifugal pump and explain the data presented in a pump curve, including head, flow rate, efficiency, and power;
design a hydraulics system with components, including hydraulic fluid, pump, reservoir, motor, cylinders, valves, and flow controllers;
identify and compare different types of turbomachines, including pumps and turbines;
describe and differentiate the applications of turbomachines, including pumps and turbines; and
explain the concept of tribology and identify the associated variables of tribology such as film thicknesses and pressures.

The Engineering Career Cluster focuses on planning, designing, testing, building, and maintaining machines, structures, materials, systems, and processes using empirical evidence and science, technology, and math principles. This career cluster includes occupations ranging from mechanical engineer and drafter to electrical engineer and mapping technician.

Students enrolled in Mechanics of Materials describe the mechanical behavior of engineering materials, including metals, ceramics, polymers, composites, welds, and adhesives, and the applications of load, deformation, stress and strain relationships for deformable bodies, and mechanical elements relevant to engineers. The course includes axially loaded members, buckling of columns, torsional members, beams, and failure.

Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.
Scientific hypotheses and theories. Students are expected to know that:

Scientific inquiry. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world using scientific and engineering practices. Scientific methods of investigation are descriptive, comparative, or experimental. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked. Student learning for different types of investigations include descriptive investigations, which involve collecting data and recording observations without making comparisons; comparative investigations, which involve collecting data with variables that are manipulated to compare results; and experimental investigations, which involve processes similar to comparative investigations but in which a control is identified.

Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world involving its own set of ethical standards about how the process of science should be carried out. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods (scientific methods) and ethical and social decisions that involve science (the application of scientific information).

Science consists of recurring themes and making connections between overarching concepts. Recurring themes include systems, models, and patterns. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested, while models allow for boundary specification and provide tools for understanding the ideas presented. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories; and

scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well established and highly reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed.
Scientific practices. Students should be able to ask questions, plan and conduct investigations to answer questions, and explain phenomena using appropriate tools and models.
Engineering practices. Students should be able to identify problems and design solutions using appropriate tools and models.

Statics is a gateway course into most engineering majors such as aerospace, mechanical, civil, and biomedical engineering. Students learn the elements of statics that include the forces in structures that are in equilibrium and usually not moving. This includes forces calculated in two dimensions, free-body diagrams, distributed loads, centroids, and friction as applied to cables, trusses, beams, machines, gears, and mechanisms. Students explore scenarios where objects remain stationary, emphasizing the importance of balance and stability in engineering design. This course not only equips students with theoretical knowledge but also empowers them with practical skills that are indispensable in real-world engineering scenarios.

Students enrolled in Mechanical Design I demonstrate knowledge and skills associated with design and manufacture of mechanical systems. Fundamental mechanisms are introduced such as gears, belts, threaded elements, and four-bar mechanisms. Basic manufacturing processes such as stamping, injection molding, casting, machining, and assembly are explored through reverse engineering. The mechanisms encountered through reverse engineering enable the exploration of product functionality. Students compare engineering choices made for components, materials, and manufacturing processes. Emphasis is placed on team collaboration and professional documentation.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.

Students enrolled in Mechanical Design II demonstrate knowledge and skills associated with the design development and validation of a prototype solution to meet a given set of requirements. Students identify project stakeholders; manage projects; evolve requirements; model system solutions; develop, test, and refine prototypes; and validate project solutions. Emphasis is placed on budget management, professional documentation, conducting project status updates, critiquing design reviews, and team collaboration.

generate a project management plan that includes time and deliverable estimates;

review and update periodically the project management plan based on appropriate industry standard practices such as stage-gate and Agile Project Management; team structure and formation; and project modeling such as flow charts, Gantt charts, Program Evaluation Review Technique (PERT), critical path method, and work breakdown structures;
create model or test proposals for review; and
compare project management approaches such as stage-gate and Agile.
describe how an engineer's professional responsibility applies to stakeholders;
develop a journey map or equivalent tool to model how the stakeholder interacts with the product; and

identify and solicit stakeholder requirements;
generate, refine, and document product and project requirements throughout the project;
document requirements in correct format with appropriate standards such as National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), military, and International Council on Systems Engineering (INCOSE);
verify that each requirement can be associated to at least one stakeholder;
verify that each stakeholder can be associated to at least one requirement;
discuss the importance of the relation between requirements and respective stakeholders;
analyze how key mechanical design concepts such as heat transfer, mechanics of materials, statics, or fluids impact the design process, design requirements, and design decisions; and
explain how requirements drive the project.
create models of various mechanical system concepts;
compare different models against the appropriate requirements;
extract new system requirements from the models;
create models to communicate engineering design solutions to stakeholders for a project;
discuss conservation principles of energy, matter, and motion; and
apply conservation principles throughout the system model.
select the key requirements for the problem;
generate multiple means to address each key requirement to populate a morphological matrix;
generate multiple integrated solutions by selecting means from each requirement for further modeling and refinement; and
calculate the total number of possible solutions captured in the generated morphological matrix.

apply ideation tools to generate multiple concepts for a problem; and
compare the ideation tools based on the rules, number of people, representation, and purpose.
use and explain absolute or relative decision matrices to prune a set of concepts;
use and explain pair-wise comparisons to prune a set of concepts;
use and explain pro-con lists to prune a set of concepts;
explain why it is important to use multiple pruning tools in design; and
explain why the pruning tools are not for selecting concepts.
develop prototyping proposals that include cost, time, and effort estimates; desired information; and testing plans;
use appropriate tools and materials to fabricate prototypes;
evaluate and execute testing plans for each prototype to gather information or check requirement satisfaction;
extract and document new requirements from prototyping and testing; and
justify the purpose for each physical or virtual model constructed against the cost of making the model.
construct geometric models and drawings to represent designed system;
justify and use appropriate analytical and simulation tools to correlate the changes in parameters of the models with changes in the performance of the modeled system;
justify design decisions using requirements such as functionality, cost, performance, or time;
use appropriate tools and materials to fabricate a final prototype;
develop final product documents such as bill of materials, assembly models, user manual, and assembly instructions; and
explain the evolution of requirements between earlier and final prototypes.
analyze information gained from testing and simulation to document new or refined requirements;
document simulations or tests using an appropriate report template;
design and execute simulations or tests to validate functional requirements are met;
explain why engineering design processes are iterative; and
discuss how continuous improvement and design iteration are related.
create budgets for initial project costs such as raw materials, purchased parts, salvaged parts, hardware, taxes, shipping, and handling categories;
create a Bill of Materials cost report for the final build;
compare and explain any differences between the final product build cost and the project budget;
monitor and update the project budget throughout the duration of the project;
prepare budget status reports that include explanations of spenddown rates and changes to the budget; and
explain the importance of budget tracking in design projects.

Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards, industry-relevant technical knowledge, and college and career readiness skills for students to further their education and succeed in current and emerging professions.

The Engineering Career Cluster focuses on planning, designing, testing, building, and maintaining machines, structures, materials, systems, and processes using empirical evidence and science, technology, and math principles. This career cluster includes occupations ranging from mechanical engineer and drafter to electrical engineer and mapping technician.

Students enrolled in Aerospace Design I demonstrate knowledge and skills associated with the design evolution and emerging trends of aircraft and aerospace systems. Fundamental concepts such as forces of flight, structures, aerodynamics, propulsion, stability and control, and orbital mechanics are introduced as related to design decisions for atmospheric and space flight. These concepts are related to mission requirements and solution approaches.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

The student discusses ethics pertaining to engineering. The student is expected to identify and discuss the importance of professionalism, standards of conduct, and ethics as defined by the Texas Engineering Practice Act and rules concerning the practice of engineering and surveying.
The student understands that there are different stages of the engineering design process and the importance of working through each stage as part of an iterative process. The student is expected to:

Atmospheric flight. The student identifies and relates the three axes of an aircraft, the four forces of flight, and the components used for stability and control of the aircraft. The student is expected to:
Lift and drag. The student explains how lift and drag are generated by an aircraft and how they change during flight. The student is expected to:
Weight and balance. The student recognizes that components have mass, weight, and location resulting in moments that are balanced by control surfaces. The student is expected to:

Aerospace structures. The student explains and compares and contrasts types of structures such as truss, semi-monocoque, monocoque. The student is expected to:
Space flight and orbital mechanics. The student knows properties of orbital mechanics as they relate to space flight and the impact of the space environment on design. The student is expected to:

Alternate applications for aerospace design. The student examines alternate applications for aerospace design in various industries, including the automotive, naval, and other commercial industries. The student is expected to:

Aircraft systems. The student explores and discusses other aircraft systems such as navigation, communication, entertainment, flight control, actuation, energy storage and management, and propulsion. The student is expected to:
explain the importance of defining an engineering problem as an initial step in the engineering design process;
describe the research stage of the engineering design process;
define ideation and conceptualization and discuss the role these processes play in innovation and problem solving;
explain the processes of selecting an idea or concept for detailed prototype design, development, and testing;
describe the purpose of non-technical drawings, technical drawings, models, and prototypes in designing a solution to an engineering problem;
describe the process of relevant experimental design, conducting tests, collecting data, and analyzing data to evaluate potential solutions;
explain how the engineering design process is iterative and the role reflection plays in developing an optimized engineering solution; and
describe the purpose of effective communication of the engineering solution as obtained through the engineering design process to various audiences.
discuss strategies for managing time, setting deadlines, and prioritizing to accomplish goals;
identify constraints and describe the importance of planning around constraints, including budgets, resources, and materials;
define milestones and deliverables and explain the advantages of dividing a large project into smaller milestones and deliverables;
identify different types of communication and explain how different types of communication lead to successful teamwork on a shared project in a professional setting; and
identify strategies to solve problems and describe how problem solving is utilized to accomplish personal and team objectives.
discuss principles of critique such as describing, analyzing, interpreting, and evaluating;

identify and demonstrate teamwork skills such as sensemaking where a team member recognizes another team member who requires additional clarity and then addresses the team member by providing clarity;
identify methods for structuring projects such as Gantt charts, work breakdown structure, Agile, and critical path method; and
discuss the importance of contributing to positive and productive group dynamics to enhance teamwork.
use professional standards and templates to generate documents such as executive summaries, test reports, failure documents, system black box models, engineering notebooks, and drawing packages;
select the document format to communicate essential information for identified stakeholders; and
explain and justify the structure and sequence of how the information is presented in the engineering documents.
identify and discuss successes and failures in human efforts to fly prior to powered flight;
research and discuss innovations in aircraft prior to the jet age and explain how world events impacted these innovations;
research and discuss innovations in aircraft after the beginning of the jet age and explain how world events impacted these innovations;
research and discuss innovations in rockets prior to human spaceflight and explain how world events impacted these innovations;
research and discuss innovations in rockets after the first human spaceflight and explain how world events impacted these innovations; and
discuss the history of regulation of aircraft and the role of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
identify and describe classes of aircraft such as single-engine land (SEL), gyroplane, powered-lift, and glider using the FAA categories;
categorize aircraft by attributes such as piston engine, turboprop, powered or unpowered, and drones or piloted;
compare aircraft categories and use cases for each category; and
research and discuss emerging trends in aircraft such as airships, rotary powered aircraft, and alternative energy powered aircraft.
explain the relationships between atmospheric temperature, pressure, density, and altitude;
identify and describe the motion about the three axes of an aircraft, including yaw, pitch, and roll;
identify and describe ways to control motion about the three axes;
identify and explain the four forces acting on aerospace vehicles in flight, including lift, drag, thrust, and weight;
explain the relationship between weight, mass, gravity, and acceleration and identify their corresponding units such as pounds-force, pound-mass, kilogram, and Newton;
discuss the difference between g-force and weight;
draw the forces of flight for a straight and level flight and a level banked turn;
identify different ways to control the forces that change the pitch, roll, and yaw of an aircraft;
identify and explain the major fixed and movable components of various aircraft to enable stability and control within the atmosphere; and
define and discuss aerodynamics as a subset of aerospace.
explain how an airfoil generates lift;
explain how the angle of attack (AoA) influences lift;
explain how to interpret a "Lift Coefficient (CL) versus AoA" chart;
define and discuss stall for an airfoil;
explain the types of drag, including profile/form, skin friction, interference, trim, and induced;
explain how the AoA influences drag;
explain how to interpret a "Drag Coefficient (CD) versus AoA" chart;
explain how changes in drag during flight impact performance such as range, altitude, and power requirements;
define and discuss Lift-to-Drag (L/D) ratio;
explain how to interpret an L/D chart;
identify the maximum L/D ratio from a chart to determine the optimal glide speed for maximum range;
research and discuss other systems that use airfoils such as windmills, fans, and propelling aircraft; and
explain how a plane can fly without engine power and in some cases can gain altitude to stay aloft for extended time and distance.
identify and calculate moments created by the forces of flight;
define and discuss center of gravity (CG);
define and discuss center of pressure (CP);
explain how the locations of the CP and CG influence the stability of an aircraft; and
create a model of an aircraft with variable configurations for CG and CP to determine stability of an aircraft.
identify engineering computational tools such as computer-aided design (CAD), finite element analysis (FEA), or computational fluid dynamics (CFD); and
explain the applications of engineering computational tools used in aerospace design.
analyze a mission to generate a list of atmospheric mission requirements such as payload, range, cruise, take-off length, landing length, climb gradient, altitude, and land or sea;
analyze a mission to generate a list of space mission requirements such as payload, altitude, vibration sensitivity, launch conditions, environmental conditions, and recovery;
explain how the mission requirements are interrelated;
discuss how the mission requirements relate to the aircraft and spacecraft categories;
discuss how mission requirements relate to the overall aircraft design; and
interpret a mission profile and explain how it impacts mission requirements.
identify and explain how a piston powered aircraft delivers thrust with respect to altitude limits and speed limitations;
identify and explain how a turboprop powered aircraft delivers thrust with respect to design requirements such as cost, operation cost, reliability, power, altitude limits, and speed limitations;
identify and explain how a jet powered aircraft delivers thrust with respect to design requirements such as cost, operation cost, reliability, power, altitude limits, and speed limitations;
explore and explain how a rocket engine is different from a jet engine;
research and discuss the applications for solid-fuel rockets; and
research and discuss the applications for liquid-fuel rockets.
research and discuss material classes used in aerospace design such as woods, composites, metals, and plastics;
explain why specific materials might have been chosen for components on different aircraft;
discuss methods for manufacturing aircraft components such as landing gears, wings, fuselage, or canopies;
explain the impact of material and manufacturing costs on design decisions; and
explain how material requirements relate to mission requirements.
identify and discuss truss, semi-monocoque, and monocoque structures;
explain why different structure types are used in various aircraft categories;
discuss how mission requirements impact the selection of the structural types for an aircraft;
identify structural components in the fuselage such as stringers, bulkheads, and skin;
identify structural components in the wings and empennage such as ribs, spars, stringers, and skin; and
compare structures used in atmospheric flight and space flight.
identify and describe orbits based on the six Keplerian Elements;
explain how changes in Keplerian Elements change the orbit;
explain how mission requirements determine specific orbit types;
describe the unique environmental conditions of operating in space for human or autonomous missions;
research and discuss methods to reach and recover a spacecraft from space; and
research and discuss emerging trends in space flight.
research and discuss how aerospace engineers contribute to automotive and naval applications to improve performance;
research and identify commercial applications for aerospace design such as heating and cooling systems, building design, and wind turbines; and
identify and discuss items at home that are impacted by aerodynamics such as fans, convection ovens, and heating and cooling systems.
explain basic functionality for aircraft systems such as navigation, communication, entertainment, flight control, and propulsion; and

Students enrolled in Aerospace Design II demonstrate knowledge and skills associated with the design and prototyping of aerospace systems. Through aerospace projects, students apply fundamental concepts such as managing an engineering project to meet mission requirements, prototyping, testing, and validating requirements. Students explore choices made for propulsion, material, and structural design as well as various ways aircraft can navigate. Emphasis is placed on team collaboration and professional documentation.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.

describe and implement the stages of an engineering design process to construct a model;

generate documents such as executive summaries, reverse engineering forms, test reports, failure documents, system black box models, engineering notebooks, and drawing packages by applying professional standards and templates;

generate a final design report with an executive summary, a body with problem and solution descriptions, and appendices with additional relevant information such as the design process used, requirements compliance matrix, concept reports, and test reports.

test, evaluate, and document performance of the revised prototype in meeting project requirements; and

evaluate and select a propulsion solution that meets requirements such as piston, jet, turboprop, and rocket;
evaluate and select the number of engines to meet mission and sub-requirements; and

document the justification for the materials selected to meet component requirements.

explain navigation using an Inertial Navigation System (INS); and
explain navigation using Global Positioning Systems (GPS).

Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards, industry-relevant technical knowledge, and college and career readiness skills for students to further their education and succeed in current and emerging professions.

The Engineering Career Cluster focuses on planning, designing, testing, building, and maintaining machines, structures, materials, systems, and processes using empirical evidence and science, technology, and math principles. This career cluster includes occupations ranging from mechanical engineer and drafter to electrical engineer and mapping technician.

Students in Civil Engineering I are introduced to the basic principles and practices essential to the field of civil engineering. Throughout this course students investigate different career paths in civil engineering, explore the various specializations within the field, and understand the phases and life cycle of civil engineering projects. They also delve into the functional mathematics crucial to the profession. Additionally, the course emphasizes the importance of effective project document structure and project management, ethical considerations, and the impact of civil engineering on the natural and built environment.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.

explain the civil engineering project conception, scope, proposal, contract, design planning and development, construction documents, bid and specifications, construction, and closeout phase; and
identify and sequence the phases of a project life cycle.

identify and describe the importance of potential components in a feasibility report, including soil analysis, existing land entitlements, existing topography, federal emergency management agency (FEMA) floodplain location and elevation, existing utility and locations, environmental studies, and adjacent rights-of-way;
identify and quantify costs and benefits associated with a proposed civil engineering project, including initial investments, operational expenses, and anticipated returns;
conduct a cost-benefit analysis for a small civil engineering project;
identify common risks associated with civil engineering projects, including technical, financial, environmental, and regulatory risks;
describe methodologies for conducting risk analysis such as probability assessment, impact analysis, and risk prioritization;
develop a feasibility report for a small civil engineering project;
explain the purpose of a request for qualifications (RFQ);
evaluate RFQs based on a project's scope;
identify relevant codes and regulations impacting civil engineering projects;
define the fundamental components of a scope of work document, including project description, stakeholders, objectives, deliverables, scope exclusions, milestones, schedule, and signature block; and
develop a scope of work document for a small civil engineering project.
identify various conceptual schematic design drawings, sketches, and diagrams that explore design solutions and communicate design concepts;
generate a conceptual schematic design drawing, sketch, or diagram that effectively communicates a design concept;

explain the purpose and application of common civil engineering calculations such as superelevation, flow line, beam analysis, cost amortization, materials testing, plasticity index, and differential leveling;
evaluate engineering plans and specifications using quality control and quality assurance (QCQA) processes; and
prepare a design quantity take-off and estimate of probable construction cost.

identify the tools and technology used in civil engineering throughout history such as abacus, compass, scale, measuring tape, slide rule, calculator, computer-aided drafting and design, level, auto-level, grade rod, plumb bob, transit, theodolite, total station, GPS, lidar, and drones;
explain the evolution of technology used in civil engineering; and
explain the uses of design analysis and computer-aided drafting software.
identify the main stakeholders involved in final inspections such as owner, utility provider(s), designer(s), contractors, municipalities, and regulatory agencies;
develop a punch list that is organized by trade, area, or priority and identifies deficiencies in a substantially completed project; and
evaluate the completed project to identify project successes and deficiencies.

identify the sections of a construction document set, including plat, existing conditions, site plan, fire protection plan, dimensional control plan, grading plan, drainage plan, utility plan, paving plan, erosion control plan, and project detail sheets;
research and describe the purpose of a fire protection plan;
describe the components of a paving plan, including pavement sections, material types, and design details;
identify and locate construction specification documents relevant to a given project;
explain and locate the fundamental components of a construction document's legend, including symbols, line types, and typical abbreviations;
explain the process of drafting a construction document to scale;
determine and demonstrate which scale best fits a standard size drawing sheet;
explain the relationship between a construction document's specifications, plans, legend, and scale; and
identify and explain the differences between design drawings and record drawings.
explain the significance of systematic organizational structure for project documents;
develop a systematic organizational structure for project documents that considers factors such as project phase, discipline, and document type;
develop a consistent naming convention for project documents; and
implement and maintain a uniform naming convention for project documents.
research and describe time management techniques such as using Gantt charts, schedules, critical paths, and man-power projections for project management;
demonstrate effective communication skills in written and oral formats to facilitate collaboration in a project team; and
explain how project team dynamics impact project outcomes and member morale.
research and identify the fundamental engineering ethics established by the Texas Board of Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors; and
analyze root causes and lessons learned from historical examples or case studies involving ethical misconduct in civil engineering projects.
describe the potential impacts, costs, and benefits of sustainable practices on local and global communities, environments, and economies;
apply cost-benefit analysis to sustainability standards used throughout the project life cycle to evaluate their economic, environmental, and social trade-offs;
describe governmental agencies that regulate environmental impact at the federal, state, and local level;
describe the potential impacts of construction on the natural world, including flora, fauna, groundwater, surface water, soil, Earth's atmosphere, air quality, and waterways; and
describe methods used by engineers to mitigate and remediate the effects of construction on the natural world.
describe methods of population projection for sizing water and wastewater facilities;
describe water quality standards using prescribed units of measure;
research and explain regulations for water quantity design requirements by jurisdiction;
research and explain regulations for wastewater quantity design requirements by jurisdiction;
research and describe methods of water and wastewater treatment;
research and describe methods of solid waste management;
research and describe methods of controlling hazardous waste; and
research and describe methods of measuring and managing air quality.

Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards, industry-relevant technical knowledge, and college and career readiness skills for students to further their education and succeed in current and emerging professions.

The Engineering Career Cluster focuses on planning, designing, testing, building, and maintaining machines, structures, materials, systems, and processes using empirical evidence and science, technology, and math principles. This career cluster includes occupations ranging from mechanical engineer and drafter to electrical engineer and mapping technician.

Students in Civil Engineering II apply the principles and practices essential to various subdisciplines within civil engineering. Throughout this course, students develop knowledge and skills essential to the design development and construction of a civil engineering project. The students explore the impacts and constraints on the design of a project. They also delve into the functional mathematics crucial to the profession. Additionally, the course emphasizes the importance of effective project document structure and project management, ethical considerations, and the impact of civil engineering on the natural and built environment.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

describe and implement the stages of an engineering design process to construct a model;
explain how factors, including complexity, scope, resources, ethics, regulations, manufacturability, maintainability, and technology, impact stages of the engineering design process;
explain how stakeholders impact an engineering design process; and
analyze how failure is often an essential component of the engineering design process.
research and explain the process and phases of project management, including initiating, planning, executing, and closing;
explain the roles and responsibilities of team members, including project managers and leads;
research and evaluate methods and tools available for managing a project;
discuss the importance of developing and implementing a system for the organization of project documentation such as file naming conventions, document release control, and version control;
describe how project requirements, constraints, and deliverables impact the project schedule and influence an engineering design;
explain how a project budget, including materials, equipment, and labor, is developed and maintained; and
describe the importance of management of change (MOC) and how MOC applies to project planning.
describe the roles and objectives of project stakeholders, including engineer, owner, architect, contractor, subcontractors, project manager, end users, regulatory agencies, and the public; and

describe the mission and membership benefits of industry organizations such as the American Society of Civil Engineers, the National Society of Professional Engineers, and the Society of Women Engineers.

describe the essential technical knowledge and functions in a variety of civil engineering subdisciplines, including environmental, geotechnical, transportation, structural, water resources, and construction;

explain how different types of projects within civil engineering subdisciplines, including public works, transportation, urban development, water resources, and utility projects, impact the built environment; and
identify and describe types of civil engineering projects.
research and describe regulations established by the American Disabilities Act relevant to site design;
identify local codes and regulations for a civil engineering project;
describe the potential impacts of local codes and regulations on civil engineering projects; and
describe the purpose of a plat and easements for a civil engineering project.
analyze or develop a feasibility report for a civil engineering project;
develop and analyze the scope of work document for a civil engineering project;
calculate monetary value for engineering efforts on a given project;
revise and archive the draft project proposal for scope of work changes;
develop a client deliverable package that contains a fee proposal, project schedule, organizational chart, exclusions, and an engineering contract;
communicate effectively a final proposal for a civil engineering project; and
identify and evaluate lessons learned from the project proposal process.
identify and prioritize project tasks to determine the critical path of a project;
create a project critical path diagram;
evaluate project tasks and the critical path to develop a project schedule;
create a Gantt chart for all the project activities in a project; and
assess a project schedule for opportunities to improve project efficiencies.
create a concept site plan using existing schematics, survey data, and regulatory design manuals;
identify existing and proposed utility providers, including electric, water, sewer, gas, and telecommunications providers, at a project site;
research and identify existing plats and easements for a project site; and
revise and finalize a project site plan to reflect analyzed site data, including utilities, geotechnical, right-of-way, water resources, environmental, survey, and transportation data.
describe storm event probability based on historical models;
describe methods used, including Rational method, Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS), Soil Conservation Service (SCS), and unit hydrograph, to calculate flow rate;
analyze existing topography at the project site to determine drainage patterns;
delineate existing and proposed drainage areas impacting a project site to determine the change in stormwater runoff generated by a project design;
research and describe methods of stormwater mitigation and water quality treatment;
calculate the existing flow rates for a 5-year and a 100-year storm event for a project site using the Rational method;
analyze and calculate the proposed flow rates for a 5-year and a 100-year storm event for a project design;
determine the required stormwater remediation techniques for a 100-year storm event by comparing existing and proposed runoff quantities;
describe methods of stormwater conveyance, including channel, culvert, and pipe;
calculate the hydraulics of a stormwater conveyance using the continuity equation, energy equation, and Bernoulli's equation;
design a conveyance system such as a pipe, culvert, or open channel to convey stormwater runoff for a 100-year storm event using the calculated data;
create a plan and profile sheet of a drainage system, including surface elevations, slopes, conveyance system dimensions, material, and pipe invert elevations; and
describe potential impacts of a drainage analysis for a project.

identify and explain the components of a geotechnical report, including boring samples and logs, soil types and classifications, pavement recommendations, foundations recommendations, and soil preparations;
identify and determine the soil classifications at a project site using the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) Web Soil Survey (WSS);
calculate the plasticity index of soil from a project site;
research and describe methods of soil preparation;
research and explain how geotechnical results impact pavement recommendations used in civil engineering projects;
research and select the most effective pavement section for a project; and
describe the impact of a geotechnical analysis for a project.

identify and analyze the various types of building foundations, including raft, monolithic slab, slab on grade, pier and beam, spread footing, mat footing, drilled piers, pylons, waffle slab, and post-tension slab;
describe the forces common to structural engineering calculations, including gravity, tension, compression, flexure, and torsion;
describe the loads common to structural engineering calculations, including dead load, live load, environmental loads, and other loads such as lateral and concentrated loads;
diagram and explain how applied loads and forces are resisted in a structure and transferred to the Earth;
diagram a simply supported beam subjected to loading conditions to determine reaction forces;
sketch diagrams to determine the maximum shear and moment resulting in the beam;
identify the different types of trusses, including simple, planar, and space frame trusses;
diagram a truss subjected to loading conditions to determine reaction forces and identify the zero force members;
explain why design loads are dictated by building codes; and
describe potential impacts of a structural analysis for a project.
identify and describe various types of transportation engineering specializations such as rail, aviation, roadway, highway, and marine;
research and explain the benefits of having a professional transportation engineering certification;

research and explain the benefits of membership in a transportation engineering organization such as Institute for Transportation Engineers (ITE), American Society of Highway Engineers (ASHE), American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO), and WTS International;
determine stopping sight distance of a roadway given the design speed and grade;

research and describe the impacts of transportation design elements, including grades, superelevation, design speed, friction factor, lane widths, vertical curves, horizontal curves, roadway classification, acceleration, and deceleration;
analyze the level of service of a roadway to determine if operating conditions are adequate;
identify and explain the components of a traffic impact analysis (TIA), including data collection summary, trip analysis, turn lane analysis, project phasing, and sight visibility analysis;
research and identify methods of traffic data collection;
collect and calculate traffic count data at a project site and analyze the results of the traffic count to determine peak hour trips and traffic mitigation;
determine the peak hour trips generated by a given land use from a ITE Trip Generation Manual;
research and describe traffic level of service for various roadways;
determine if a turn lane is warranted based on peak hour trips and traffic volume; and
describe potential impacts of a transportation analysis for a project.
develop project construction documents that includes design plans, specifications, and a cost estimate for a civil engineering project;
develop the analysis reports for a civil engineering project;
generate a demolition sheet that contains existing topography, property lines, easements, utilities, rights-of-way, drainage infrastructure, and structures, and identifies items to be demolished;
develop a fire protection plan for a project;
generate a paving plan that shows the limits and types of pavement necessary for a project;
generate a site plan that labels proposed improvements for a project;
generate a site dimensional control plan containing measurements for all site improvements for a project;
generate a grading plan that documents proposed elevations and topography in comparison to existing topography for a project;
generate drainage plans that document the existing drainage patterns, proposed drainage plan, and drainage infrastructure for a project;
generate a utility plan that documents existing and proposed utility types, locations, and materials for a project;
generate an erosion control plan that identifies erosion control best management practices (BMP) defined by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) for a project; and
explain the importance of a quality control review and complete a quality control review of the construction documents of the project.
identify components of a bid tabulation, including item description, material quantity, unit measure, unit price, and total price;
compare a project bid tabulation with corresponding construction documents to verify all items are included;
create a project bid tabulation; and
identify and compile the parts of civil engineering project manual.
track team goals to verify completion of project milestones;
explain various methods to resolve conflict within a project team;
explain how leadership impacts project outcomes and team members; and
evaluate team member performance and effectiveness in a project.
research and describe the impact of the State of Texas Engineering Practice Act; and
analyze and discuss ethical case studies using Texas Administrative Code, Title 22, Part 6, Chapter 137, Subchapter C (relating to Professional Conduct and Ethics).
research and describe sustainable building materials and methods;
identify and explain the programs and certifications that establish design criteria for engineering projects such as Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED);
explain how sustainable programs and certifications potentially impact the design elements and costs of a project;
explain how design choices potentially impact human health, the environment, and the cost of a project; and
explain how elements of the construction process potentially impact human health and the environment.

Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards, industry-relevant technical knowledge, and college and career readiness skills for students to further their education and succeed in current and emerging professions.

The Engineering Career Cluster focuses on planning, designing, testing, building, and maintaining machines, structures, materials, systems, and processes using empirical evidence and science, technology, and math principles. This career cluster includes occupations ranging from mechanical engineer and drafter to electrical engineer and mapping technician.

Students enrolled in Engineering Project Management develop cursory knowledge and essential skills to lead an engineering team through the development and construction of a project. Students assess project documentation for compliance with best management practices. They engage in project planning, risk management, team management, and stakeholder communication to ensure project completion, adherence to safety guidelines, and continuous improvement.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

The student discusses ethics pertaining to engineering. The student is expected to identify and discuss the importance of professionalism, standards of conduct, and ethics as defined by the Texas Engineering Practice Act and rules concerning the practice of engineering and surveying.

explain the importance of defining an engineering problem as an initial step in the engineering design process;
describe the research stage of the engineering design process;
define ideation and conceptualization and discuss the role these processes play in innovation and problem solving;
explain the processes of selecting an idea or concept for detailed prototype design, development, and testing;

describe the purpose of effective communication of the engineering solution as obtained through the engineering design process to various audiences.
discuss strategies for managing time, setting deadlines, and prioritizing to accomplish goals;
identify constraints and describe the importance of planning around constraints, including budgets, resources, and materials;
define milestones and deliverables and explain the advantages of dividing a large project into smaller milestones and deliverables;
identify different types of communication and explain how different types of communication lead to successful teamwork on a shared project in a professional setting; and

explain and discuss the responsibilities of workers and employers to promote safety and health in the workplace and the rights of workers to a secure workplace;

describe the elements of a safety and health program, including management leadership, worker participation, and education and training;

explain the purpose and importance of written emergency action plans and fire protection plans and describe key components of each such as evacuation plans and emergency exit routes, list of fire hazards, and identification of emergency personnel;
explain the components of a hazard communication program; and
explain and give examples of safety and health training requirements specified by standard setting organizations.
identify and prioritize engineering tasks for an engineering project plan;
identify and outline the critical path of a set of tasks in an engineering project;
develop a project budget based on billable hours and engineering tasks in a project;
track and maintain time spent on engineering tasks for a given project;
generate a Gantt chart for an engineering project, including project tasks, time to complete tasks, critical path, and schedule of tasks;
develop and implement a systematic folder structure for organizing project documents considering factors such as project phase, discipline, and document type;
apply naming conventions consistently to all project documents to facilitate efficient identification and retrieval;

evaluate an engineering project for adherence to local, state, and federal regulations;
evaluate an engineering project for adherence to best management practices; and

explain the bid process for a project, including timeline, value engineering, request for information (RFI), request for qualifications (RFQ), request for price (RFP), interview process, bid opening, bid evaluations, and bid award;
develop a quantity take-off for an engineering project; and

compare shop drawings and construction documents to identify and rectify variances;

compile and organize material specifications to create a submittal log;
analyze a construction drawing to develop applicable design questions and create an RFI document;

identify permitting stakeholders and explain stakeholder roles in the permitting process;
identify permitting entities and create a permit request;

develop a method of documentation to track project changes, including field changes, design changes, and change orders, and analyze cost and schedule impacts of project changes; and

identify and draft applicable completion documents, including certificate of occupancy, temporary certificate of occupancy, field changes, as-built or plan of record documents, and engineer's certification of substantial completion.

research federal regulatory agencies and describe the role federal regulatory agencies serve in relation to engineering projects such as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), and Army Corps of Engineers;

research state regulatory agencies such as the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), and the Texas Railroad Commission (TRC) and describe the role these agencies serve in relation to engineering projects;
research local regulatory agencies such as cities and counties and describe the role local regulatory agencies serve in relation to engineering projects; and
describe local codes and ordinances affecting construction and development activities.
identify and describe various methods of risk management related to engineering projects;
identify and analyze the potential risks in a project with respect to the project stakeholders;
develop and communicate a job hazard analysis (JHA) for a given project task;
identify factors of contingency related to an engineering project;
create a contingency estimate analyzing events that can cause potential losses to a project; and
present a risk management plan for a given project.
describe value engineering;
identify and analyze common areas of engineering projects that are susceptible to value engineering;
analyze an existing project design and cost estimate to identify potential cost saving areas;
describe an opinion of probable cost (OPC) associated with an engineering project;
generate an OPC for an engineering project, including construction mobilization, material cost, material quantities, waste disposal, contingency, and total price; and
create a cost-benefit analysis of an engineering project that compares the monetary cost of the project to the benefit to end user.
identify and describe the various team roles for an engineering project;
research and describe various project management methodologies;
create a schedule of roles for team members in an engineering project;
conduct an effective kick-off meeting to communicate the project management plan for a given engineering project;
evaluate how project team dynamics impact the successful completion of a project;
prepare and document effective meeting agendas;
record, prepare, and distribute clear and accurate meeting minutes;
research and describe effective leadership qualities;
research and identify examples of effective leadership styles;
identify and describe personal leadership styles and strengths; and
evaluate how student leadership styles impact the success of the project team.

Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards, industry-relevant technical knowledge, and college and career readiness skills for students to further their education and succeed in current and emerging professions.

The Engineering Career Cluster focuses on planning, designing, testing, building, and maintaining machines, structures, materials, systems, and processes using empirical evidence and science, technology, and math principles. This career cluster includes occupations ranging from mechanical engineer and drafter to electrical engineer and mapping technician.

Students enrolled in Architectural Engineering use principles of engineering and design tools to create innovative, functional, and sustainable buildings. Students develop cursory knowledge and essential skills to understand the design of buildings, including the mechanical, electrical, plumbing, and structural systems, while also planning the construction process. They engage in project planning, building and system analysis, site investigation, and the integration of sustainable design and construction practices for an architectural engineering project.

Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other organizations that foster leadership and career development in the profession such as student chapters of related professional associations.
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

identify and describe the fundamental parts of a building, including foundations, floors, walls, roof, and utility systems;
identify and describe the visual design elements of various building types, including residential, commercial, institutional, and industrial buildings; and
research and describe the evolution of the built space and development of building forms.
identify and describe common building materials such as wood, masonry, concrete, metal, glass, aggregate, and plastic;
identify and describe common roofing materials such as thatch, wood, metal, sod, and asphalt;
describe traditional construction methods such as wood framing, tilt-wall, masonry, and steel;
describe contemporary construction methods such as prefabricated, modular, and additive construction (3D printing);
identify and describe standard building methods such as casting, cutting, drilling, driving, and fastening for the construction of buildings;
research and describe resilient building materials, methods, and costs; and
describe how building material selection is impacted influenced by certifications such as Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) or Energy Star.
explain the purpose of local building codes, including public health and safety, structural, and utility codes;
describe land use regulations to identify zoning ordinances and allowable uses of real property;
describe how zoning regulations are used to control land use and development;

identify standard accessibility features such as ramps, elevators, parking, handrails, and fire alarm horn strobe as specified in codes and regulations such as the American Disability Act (ADA) and the Texas Accessibility Standards (TAS);
explain how codes and building regulations constrain aspects of building design, including the structure, site design, utilities, and building usage;
explain how codes and building regulations constrain aspects of building construction, including the structure, site construction, utilities, and building usage; and
classify a building according to its use type, occupancy, and construction type using the International Building Code.

determine the united soil classification system designation from a site soil sample analysis;

describe the loads common to structural engineering calculations, including dead load, live load, environmental, and other load paths such as lateral and concentrated;
diagram and explain how applied loads and forces are resisted in a structure and transferred to the Earth;
diagram a simply supported beam subjected to loading conditions to determine reaction forces;
sketch diagrams to determine the maximum shear and moment resulting in the beam;
identify the different types of trusses, including simple, planar, and space frame trusses;
diagram a truss subjected to loading conditions to determine reaction forces and identify the zero force members;
explain why design loads are dictated by building codes;

describe the purpose of various concrete admixtures, including air entrainer, reducer, retarder, and accelerator;
explain why various admixtures are selected for a project such as curing time, ambient climate, and permeability;
conduct concrete compression and splitting-tension tests and compare strength and failures in a concrete mixture; and
analyze a concrete mixture by performing a slump test.
develop a stormwater management system for a building that includes roof drainage calculations, roof drain design, and downspout sizing and location;
design ingress and egress for a building that complies with local, state, and federal codes and regulations;
develop building design and engineering plans that incorporate energy conservation techniques;
recommend and defend an appropriate foundation design for a building type;
design, modify, and plan structures using 3D software;
construct building drawings using advanced computer-aided design drafting skills;
create three-dimensional views of a building design;
create three-dimensional solid models of the building;
